items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high, but stable, on the River Windrush. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in areas close to the river around Bourton on the Water. We expect river levels in this area to remain high over the next few days. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (04/03/2025) with a dry forecast for tomorrow. 
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 05/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are  falling steadily on the lower sections of the River Thame.  The flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the area closest to the river around Stadhampton and Dorchester. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (03/03/2025) with a dry forecast for the next few days. We expect river levels to continue to fall over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Tuesday morning, 04/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message: River levels in the Lower Avon remain high due to high groundwater levels.  A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch. There is no rainfall predicted for the next 4 to 5 days. We continue to monitor river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 03/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels remain high but are slowly falling. 

Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near rivers, particularly around Longford. Property flooding is not expected.

The next few days are expected to remain mostly dry, with no significant rainfall forecast.

We are continuing to monitor river levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 10am on Wednesday 5th March, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today. Little or no further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 05/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message: River levels are high but dropping at the Stinsford river gauge on the Lower Frome. Flooding is forecast to affect low lying areas near to the River Frome in the Dorchester, West Stafford, Bockhampton, Lewell, Tincleton, Pallington, Waddock, Moreton, Wool, East Stoke, Holmebridge, Stoborough, Stoborough Green, Wareham, Redcliffe, Ridge and Swineham areas. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. There is no rainfall predicted for the next 4 to 5 days. We continue to monitor river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 03/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds following last night's high tide. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels on the River Pang continue to fall steadily. However, the flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in areas close to the river around Tidmarsh. We expect river levels to continue to fall but remain high over the next few days. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (04/03/2025) with a dry forecast for tomorrow. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 05/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60mAOD at 17:45 on 04/03/2025 and 4.65mAOD at 05:45 on 05/03/2025.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 140 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next five days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 05/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Tuesday morning’s tide at 02:00 on 04/03/2025 is higher than normal, with light North Easterly Force 2 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.09 m. The total forecast tide is 6.06 metres Chart Datum (3.01 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:45 04/03/2025 is forecast to be 22 cm lower (2.79 mAOD). Flood impacts are predicted to continue to reduce from Tuesday 04/03/2025. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 14:00 on 04/03/2025.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced. Spring tides remain, however these will reduce through the week.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding the Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced. Spring tides remain, however these will reduce through the week.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message: River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of high tides coinciding with high flows from upstream. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island this afternoon, 04/03/25, at 5.30 pm, and is forecast to reach between 4.79 and 4.93 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks and flood low lying land. The following high tide is expected tomorrow morning, 05/03/25, at 05:45 am and is forecast to reach between 4.81 and 4.95 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks again and flood low lying land. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 05/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
High Spring tide levels are expected at 14:00 pm today 04/03/2025. Flooding is possible 1 hour either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.
The flood gates remain closed at Arnside promenade. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
No further Flood Alerts are likely to be issued for this area after the midday high tide today.
This message will be updated by 17:00 PM on 04/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, this set of high spring tides has started to reduce and we are not expecting to issue any further tidal Flood Alerts.

items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. There is no current flood risk from the high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
This Tidal Flood Alert has been removed.  
There is no longer a threat of flooding from high spring tides, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, this set of high spring tides has started to reduce and we are not expecting to issue any further tidal Flood Alerts.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This alert is no longer in force due to improving conditions. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message: Groundwater levels are being kept high from previous heavy rainfall this week. They are very slowly starting to drop. We are expecting some further rainfall coming through on Wednesday. This may keep the groundwater levels high. Flooding of fields and roads is possible. Areas most at risk include: the Iwerne and the Pimperne Brook areas. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 03/03/2025.

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message: River levels in the River Bourne remain high due to the high groundwater levels.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected at the moment. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock. There is no rainfall predicted for the next 4 to 5 days. We continue to monitor river levels.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor your local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 03/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message: River levels continue to be high at Briantspuddle river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect the Piddle and tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. There is no rainfall predicted for the next 4 to 5 days. We continue to monitor river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 03/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet and its tributaries from Berwick Bassett down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are low along most of the Upper Kennet. However flooding of low lying land is expected to continue in areas close to the River Dun near Hungerford where river levels are high but stable. We expect river levels to remain high in this area for the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (04/03/2025) with a dry forecast for tomorrow. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 05/03/25, or as the situation changes.

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (04/03/2025) with a dry forecast for tomorrow  We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 05/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Shepperton to Molesey

floodArea.county: Greater London, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message: Groundwater levels are remaining high due to previous rainfall. Areas at risk include areas around the Till and the Wylye Valley. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. We are expecting some further rainfall coming on Wednesday (26th). This may keep the levels high. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 03/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but currently stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall.   Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 11/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but currently stable at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourne Valley.  Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding.  We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall.  Low lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 11/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and continue to slowly rise. In the last week, the level at Preston Candover has risen by 15cm. A small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding in Preston Candover and Old Alresford. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. It is possible that isolated properties in Old Alresford could experience internal ground floor flooding in the next 2 weeks. From today (03/03/2025) until Friday (07/03/2025), the weather is expected to be dry. Groundwater levels in the area are expected to continue slowly rising throughout this week. If further heavy rain affects the area in the coming weeks, it is possible that more widespread cellar flooding affecting properties in the Candovers and Northington may occur by the end of March. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 10/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 5th March 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 5th March 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message: Groundwater levels are high and continuing to rise slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall.  Low-lying land and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 11/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels peaked on Tuesday 25/02/2025 and have since fallen slowly by 16cm. We expect that much of the village is being affected by cellar flooding and sewerage system impacts. From today (03/03/2025) until Friday (07/03/2025), the weather is expected to be dry. Groundwater levels in Hursley may begin to rise again in response to rain recorded at the end of February. Ongoing flooding impacts are expected to continue throughout the next couple of weeks. Internal ground floor flooding impacts may occur later in March if heavy rain affects the village. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. Please ensure that pumps used to reduce water levels are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 10/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high and rising. In the last 7 days, the level at Clanville has risen by 34cm. Cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing in Appleshaw, Hatherden and Penton Grafton. Groundwater is flooding the main road into Penton Grafton and is expected to be affecting Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton. Impacts to the sewerage systems in Penton Mewsey and Appleshaw are ongoing. From Wednesday (05/03/2025), cellar flooding is expected in Kimpton. Surface water flood risk in Thruxton will increase during this week. From today (03/03/2025) until Friday (07/03/2025), the weather is expected to be dry. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising for another week in response to rain recorded towards the end of February. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 10/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high and continue to rise slowly. In the last 7 days, the level at Oakley has risen by 27cm. In Deane, cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing. Groundwater will be affecting the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. From today (03/03/2025) until Friday (07/03/2025), the weather is expected to be dry. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising for another two weeks in response to rain recorded towards the end of February. It is possible that the access road from the B3400 into Deane (at Deane Park) will need to be closed next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 10/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high and continuing to rise slowly at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding.  We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall.  Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 11/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mimram in Hertfordshire
items.message:
Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads and gardens close to the River Mimram, due to persistent rainfall in December and January, leading to high groundwater levels. 

We are monitoring the flooding that is currently affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn.

There is elevated risk of flooding caused by water emerging from a third party blocked culvert. Flooding to homes and businesses is unlikely at this time, but there may be a risk to very low-lying properties or those with basements. River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern.

Rainfall is forecast throughout today, but is expected to clear later this afternoon. The forecast is then more settled for the rest of the week.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation. 

This message will be updated by 5pm, Wednesday 5th March 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Pitton, West Tytherley, Nether Wallop and Broughton
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high. At Lopcombe Corner, the level began rising again on Saturday 01/03/2025 and has since risen by 24cm. At West Tytherley, the level is currently stable, very close to where we expect septic tanks to struggle to operate, and cellar, land and road flooding to occur in central West Tytherley. From today (03/03/2025) until Friday (07/03/2025), the weather is expected to be dry. Groundwater levels in all villages are expected to rise during this week in response to rain recorded towards the end of February. In Nether Wallop, it is possible that cellar flooding to a small number of properties could occur towards the end of the week. In Over Wallop, land and gardens may experience minor ponding of water and the river may come out of bank at Broughton. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 10/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Bourne Valley - The Winterbournes
items.message: Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Gunner, Winterbourne Dauntsey, Winterbourne Earls and Laverstock . The groundwater level at the Clarendon borehole continue to rise. We are expecting some further rainfall on Wednesday (26th). We are not currently expecting very much drop in the groundwater levels. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 03/03/2025.
